questions.question: Question 1: Who listed the four cardinal signs of inflammation?
questions.explanation:
The four cardinal signs of inflammation were first listed by Aulus Celsus. He was a Roman 
medical writer of the first century AD. These are: • Rubor - redness • Tumour - swelling • Calor - heat • Dolor - pain These signs are the hallmarks of acute inflammation. Rudolf Virchow added the fifth clinical sign of inflammation, loss of function, functio laesa.

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following stimuli can trigger an inflammatory response?
questions.explanation:
The complement system does not trigger an inflammatory response. It reacts against microbes 
and results in the production of mediators of inflammation. The major triggers of inflammation include: • Infections - bacteria, viruses, fungi, parasites, toxins • Tissue necrosis - due to ischemia, trauma, physical or chemical injuries • Foreign bodies - • Endogenous - DNA breakdown products (uric acid), cholesterol crystals, lipids • Exogenous - splinters, dirt, sutures, etc • Trauma • Immune reactions - against microbes, self-antigens, or environmental substances 76 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 3: Which of the following are cytosolic pattern-recognition receptors?
questions.explanation:
NOD-like receptors and RIG-like receptors are cytosolic pattern-recognition receptors. Pattern-recognition receptors are the cellular receptors that recognize microbes and damaged 
cells. Types of pattern-recognition receptors: • Cellular receptors for microbes - • Toll-like receptors on the plasma membrane and endosomal vesicles • C-type lectin receptors on the plasma membrane of macrophages and dendritic cells • Cytosolic receptors - • NOD-like receptors detect bacterial peptidoglycan • RIG-like receptors detect viral RNA • Circulating proteins: Mannose-binding lectin and collectins

questions.question: Question 4: Which of the following is false about the acute inflammatory process?

options.a: It is a mechanism of innate immunity
options.b: Monocytes and macrophages are mainly involved
options.c: Tissue injury is usually mild and self-limited
options.d: Local and systemic signs are prominent

questions.explanation:
The prominent cells in acute inflammation are neutrophils. The initial, rapid response to infections agents and tissue damage is called acute inflammation. It 
is a mechanism of innate immunity that occurs in response to mild and self-limited tissue 
injury. It is associated with prominent local and systemic signs. The major components of acute inflammation are: • Vasodilation and increased permeability of small blood vessels • Changes in the leukocytes - • Migration from the microcirculation • Accumulation at the site of inflammation • Activation to eliminate the offending agent Chronic inflammation is a mechanism of adaptive immunity and is of longer duration. It is 
associated with • Presence of lymphocytes and macrophages • Proliferation of blood vessels • Deposition of connective tissue

questions.question: Question 5: What is the most common mechanism of vascular leakage in acute inflammation?
questions.explanation:
The most common mechanism of vascular leakage in acute inflammation is the contraction of 
endothelial cells. 77 
Sold by @itachibot This is an immediate, transient response mediated by histamine, bradykinin, and leukotrienes. 
The contraction of the endothelial cells results in an increase in the interendothelial spaces. Other mechanisms of vascular leakage include: • Endothelial injury - results in endothelial cell necrosis and detachment • Transcytosis - increased transport of fluids and proteins

questions.question:
Question 6: A man is brought to the casualty with swelling after sustaining a bee sting over his face. 
Which of the following vascular changes is not observed in this condition?
questions.explanation:
Bee stings result in acute inflammation at the site of the sting. In this condition, there is decreased 
oncotic pressure due to protein leakage. There is a release of inflammatory mediators like histamine which result in the following vascular 
changes: • Vasodilation - results in erythema and stasis of blood flow • Increased vascular permeability - • Due to mediators like histamine, kinins, or endothelial injury (direct or leukocyte-induced ), or 
transcytosis • Results in leakage of proteins (reduced vascular oncotic pressure) and leukocyte migration • Increased hydrostatic pressure - results in fluid leakage from blood vessels resulting in edema The image below shows the changes seen during acute inflammation.

questions.question: Question 7: During normal blood flow in venules, which cells occupy the central axial column?
questions.explanation:
Blood flows in blood vessels as central axial/laminar column and peripheral chaotic columns. 
During normal blood flow in venules, the central axial column is occupied by the red blood cells 78 
Sold by @itachibot (RBCs). These RBCs displace the leukocytes toward the wall of the vessel (chaotic column). 
During inflammation, stasis leads to slow blood flow and reduced wall shear stress. This further 
pushes the WBCs towards a peripheral position along the endothelial surface. This is called 
margination. Subsequently, leukocytes adhere to the endothelium, then detach and bind again. This is referred 
to as rolling on the vessel wall. The cells finally come to rest and adhere firmly to the endothelial 
wall.

questions.question: Question 8: Which of the following is not true with regard to selectins?

options.b: There are L, E and P types of selectins
options.c: P-selectins are expressed on the endothelium

questions.explanation:
Selectins are a group of molecules that mediate low-affinity interactions between the leukocytes 
and the endothelium. Due to the low-affinity nature of these interactions, they are easily disrupted by the flowing blood. 
They play a major role in the initial rolling interactions of leukocytes with the vascular 
endothelium. The expression of selectins and their ligands is regulated by cytokines produced in 
response to infection and injury. There are 3 types of selectins: • L-selectin - expressed on leukocytes • E-selectin - expressed on endothelium • P-selectin - expressed on activated platelets and endothelium

questions.question: Question 9: Which of the following is not an integrin molecule?
questions.explanation:
CD 31 or platelet endothelial cell-adhesion molecule 1 (PECAM-1) is a member of the 
immunoglobulin superfamily. It is not an integrin molecule. The various endothelial and leukocyte adhesion molecules include: • Selectin family - mediates initial rolling interactions between leukocytes and endothelium • Integrin family - • Involved in migration and firm adhesion of leukocytes to the endothelium • Includes LFA-1, MAC-1, and VLA-4 • Immunoglobulin family - • PECAM (CD31) - most important adhesion molecule for diapedesis • ICAM-1 - binds to  2 integrins on leukocytes

questions.question: Question 10: Which of the following is not a ligand for integrins?
questions.explanation:
79 
Sold by @itachibot The ligands for integrins include: • ICAM-1 (CD54) • ICAM-2 (CD102) • VCAM-1 (CD106)

questions.question: Question 11: Sialyl-Lewis X is linked to which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Sialyl-Lewis X refers to sialylated oligosaccharides bound to mucin-like glycoprotein. These 
molecules function as ligands for selectins. The expression of selectins and their ligands is regulated by cytokines produced in response to 
infection and injury.

questions.question:
Question 12: Which molecule plays a major role in the following phenomenon seen in leukocytes? 70 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The image shows diapedesis by leukocytes. CD31 or platelet endothelial cell adhesion molecule 
(PECAM-1) plays a major role in diapedesis. Diapedesis or transmigration refers to the migration of the leukocytes through the endothelium. It 
mainly occurs in postcapillary venules.

questions.question:
Question 13: In patients with acute respiratory distress syndrome, which of the following cells are the 
major cause of tissue injury?
questions.explanation:
In acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), acute tissue injury is caused mainly by 
neutrophils. ARDS is a clinical syndrome manifested as a result of severe lung injury. The initiating event is 
alveolar epithelial cell damage. It is characterized by acute inflammation, causing increased 
pulmonary vascular permeability and edema. Neutrophils adhere to the activated endothelium and migrate into the interstitium and the alveoli. 
Here, they degranulate and release inflammatory mediators. These include: • Proteases • Reactive oxygen species • Cytokines Macrophages are involved in the stage of resolution.

questions.question:
Question 14: Infection with which of the following organisms would produce an inflammatory infiltrate 
with neutrophilic predominance beyond 48 hours?
questions.explanation:
80 
Sold by @itachibot In Pseudomonas infection, the inflammatory infiltrate has a neutrophilic predominance for 
several days. Normally, in acute inflammation, neutrophils predominate the inflammatory infiltrate during the 
first 6 to 24 hours. However, they are short-lived, and disappear within 24 to 48 hours, following 
which they are replaced by monocytes. Monocytes survive longer and also proliferate in the tissues. Thus, they become the dominant 
population in prolonged inflammatory reactions. The exceptions to this pattern include: • Pseudomonas infections - neutrophilic dominance in the infiltrate for several days • Viral infections - lymphocytes are the initial cells • Allergic reactions - eosinophils are the main cell type • Some types of hypersensitivity - dominated by activated lymphocytes, macrophages, and plasma 
cells

questions.question: Question 15: Which of the following is involved in inducing the migration of leukocytes to sites of injury?
questions.explanation:
C5a induces the migration of leukocytes to the site of injury. It functions as an endogenous 
chemoattractant. Both exogenous and endogenous substances can act as chemoattractants. The most common 
exogenous agents include bacterial products like peptides with N-formylmethionine terminal 
amino acids and certain lipids. Endogenous chemoattractants include several chemical mediators: • Cytokines - particularly those of the chemokine family (IL-8) • Complement system components - particularly C5a • Arachidonic acid metabolites - mainly leukotriene B4

questions.question: Question 16: Which of the following is an opsonin?
questions.explanation:
C3b functions as an opsonin. Opsonization is the process of coating a foreign particle and preparing it for phagocytosis. The 
substances involved in this process are called opsonins and include: • Mannose-binding lectin • C3b, C4b, C5b • IgM and Fc receptor of IgG • CRP • Fibrinogen 81 
Sold by @itachibot Elie Metchnikoff was the first person to describe the process of phagocytosis, and is hence known 
as the Father of Innate Immunity.

questions.question: Question 17: Which of the following does not have antioxidant action?
questions.explanation:
Myeloperoxidase is an oxidative enzyme, not an antioxidant. Antioxidants provide protection against potentially harmful oxygen-derived radicals. Serum, 
tissue fluids, and host cells possess antioxidant mechanisms. These include: • Catalase • Superoxide dismutase • Glutathione peroxidase • Iron-free fraction of transferrin • Carotenoids • Ceruloplasmin Myeloperoxidase is an oxidative enzyme with antimicrobial activity. It is seen in azurophil 
(primary) granules of neutrophils. It is involved in the production of hypochlorous acid and 
destroys microbes by means of halogenation and lipid peroxidation.

questions.question: Question 18: Oxygen-dependent killing is done through which of the following?
questions.explanation:
NADPH oxidase is involved in the oxygen-dependent killing of microbes. It results in generation 
of reactive oxygen intermediates. This process is called the oxidative burst. It involves the generation of H2O2, and eventually 
hypochlorous acid. This H2O2-MPO-halide system is the most efficient bactericidal system of 
neutrophils. 82 
Sold by @itachibot Carotenoids, glutathione peroxidase, and the iron-free fraction of transferrin are antioxidants or 
free radical scavengers that prevent oxygen-mediated injury.

questions.question:
Question 19: A 7-month-old male infant was brought with a 2-day history of fever and abscess over the 
neck. The mother reveals that the child has had similar recurrent infections in the past. The 
result of the nitroblue tetrazolium dye reduction test was found to be abnormal. What is the 
most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario and abnormal nitroblue tetrazolium dye reduction test are suggestive 
of chronic granulomatous disease (CGD). CGD is a rare primary immunodeficiency of phagocytes. It is an X-linked recessive disorder due to 
the deficiency in the NADPH oxidase enzyme. This is important in the respiratory or oxidative 
burst. It usually manifests in the first year of life with recurrent pyogenic infections with 
catalase-positive organisms, including: • Staphylococcus aureus • Escherichia coli • Aspergillus species

questions.question:
Question 20: A nitroblue tetrazolium test is performed in a child with recurrent infections. Functions of 
which of the following are assessed by this test?
questions.explanation:
Nitroblue tetrazolium test (NBT) is done to assess the function of phagocytes. The principle is based on the color change of the colorless nitroblue tetrazolium compound to a 
deep blue when exposed to reactive oxygen species (ROS). The higher the nitroblue test score, the 
better the cell is at producing ROS. In chronic granulomatous disease, there is an NADPH oxidase defect. Hence, the phagocyte is 
unable to produce reactive oxygen species or radicals required for bacterial killing, which results 
in recurrent infections. Hence, there is a reduced color change with the NBT test.

questions.question: Question 21: Patients with which of the following conditions have defective phagolysosome formation?
questions.explanation:
Defective phagolysosome formation is seen in patients with Chediak–Higashi syndrome 
(CHS). It is a rare autosomal recessive defect. There is an abnormal fusion of azurophilic lysosomes of neutrophils and cytoplasmic granules of 
monocytes and lymphocytes, which leads to the presence of giant lysosomal granules. Hence, 
there is abnormal post-phagocytic phagolysosomal fusion, degranulation, and impaired 
microbicidal activity. There is rapid neutrophil turnover leading to low counts. Clinical features include: • Recurrent infections - • Commonly affect the skin, upper and lower respiratory tract 83 
Sold by @itachibot • Common organisms - Staphylococcus aureus, Haemophilus influenzae, Group A 
Streptococcus, Gram-negative enteric (Klebsiella, Proteus, Shigella, Pseudomonas) • Accelerated phase in some patients - • Hemophagocytic syndrome and aggressive lymphoma • These patients require bone marrow transplantation • Albinism with neurological defects

questions.question: Question 22: What is frustrated phagocytosis?

options.a: Release of lysosomal contents due to damaged membrane
options.b: Engulfment of infectious pathogens and degradation by phagolysosome
options.c: Release of lysosomal enzymes when phagocytes cannot engulf targets

questions.explanation:
The term frustrated phagocytosis refers to the release of large amounts of lysosomal contents into 
the external environment due the inability of the phagocytes to engulf. When immune complexes are deposited on relatively flat immovable surfaces, the phagocytes are 
unable to surround and ingest them. In this case, the activation signals lead to an uncontrolled 
release of the lysosomal contents, despite lack of phagocytosis. This is known as frustrated 
phagocytosis. Other processes may lead to the release of lysosomal contents into the external environment: • Controlled secretion of granule contents - normal response of activated leukocytes • Damage to the phagolysosome membrane by certain phagocytosed substances like urate crystals

questions.question: Question 23: What does the following image show?
questions.explanation:
The image shows the phenomenon of emperipolesis. Here, intact hematopoietic cells are seen 
within the cytoplasm of the host cell without any damage. The cells frequently involved are neutrophils, lymphocytes, and plasma cells. Both the cells are 
viable and there are no physiological and morphological consequences to either of them. 84 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 25: In which of the following is major basic protein seen?
questions.explanation:
The major basic protein is the predominant constituent of the crystalline core of the eosinophil 
granule. It is also called proteoglycan-2 and is encoded by the PRG2 gene. This protein is involved in: • Antiparasitic defense mechanisms - functions as a cytotoxin and helminthotoxin • Immune hypersensitivity reactions • Lysis of epithelial cells

questions.question:
Question 26: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding neutrophil extracellular traps 
(NETs)?

options.a: TxA2 is the major product in platelets

questions.explanation:
Neutrophil extracellular traps (NETs) are not involved in phagocytosis. This is because the nuclei 
of the neutrophils are lost during NET formation, leading to their death. Hence, they cannot 
phagocytose pathogens. NETs are networks of extracellular fibers that consist of a viscous meshwork of nuclear 
chromatin. They trap microbes at sites of infection, preventing their further spread. They 
also contain a high concentration of antimicrobial proteins like neutrophil elastase, cathepsin G, 
and histones that have a high affinity for DNA. They are produced by neutrophils in response to the following triggers: • Pathogens - Mainly bacteria and fungi • Inflammatory mediators - • Chemokines • Cytokines (mainly interferons) • Complement proteins • Reactive oxygen species NETs have also been detected in the blood during sepsis. In this condition, platelet activation is 
involved in NET formation 86 
Sold by @itachibot The nuclear chromatin in the NETs is a source of nuclear antigens (histones and associated DNA) 
in systemic autoimmune diseases, particularly systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). This triggers 
autoantibody production and further clinical manifestations. 87 
Sold by @itachibot Inflammatory Mediators and Granulomatous Inflammation
